metadata.title: Combining positron emission tomography/computed tomography, radiomics, and sentinel lymph node mapping for nodal staging of endometrial cancer patients
metadata.abstract: Objective To evaluate the combination of positron emission tomography/computed tomography (PET/CT) and sentinel lymph node (SLN) biopsy in women with apparent early-stage endometrial carcinoma. The correlation between radiomics features extracted from PET images of the primary tumor and the presence of nodal metastases was also analyzed. Methods From November 2006 to March 2019, 167 patients with endometrial cancer were included. All women underwent PET/CT and surgical staging: 60/167 underwent systematic lymphadenectomy (Group 1) while, more recently, 107/167 underwent SLN biopsy (Group 2) with technetium-99m +blue dye or indocyanine green. Histology was used as standard reference. PET endometrial lesions were segmented (n=98); 167 radiomics features were computed inside tumor contours using standard Image Biomarker Standardization Initiative (IBSI) methods. Radiomics features associated with lymph node metastases were identified (Mann-Whitney test) in the training group (A); receiver operating characteristic (ROC) curves, area under the curve (AUC) values were computed and optimal cut-off (Youden index) were assessed in the test group (B). Results In Group 1, eight patients had nodal metastases (13%): seven correctly ridentified by PET/CT true-positive with one false-negative case. In Group 2, 27 patients (25%) had nodal metastases: 13 true-positive and 14 false-negative. Sensitivity, specificity, accuracy, positive predictive value, and negative predictive value of PET/CT for pelvic nodal metastases were 87%, 94%, 93%, 70%, and 98% in Group 1 and 48%, 97%, 85%, 87%, and 85% in Group 2, respectively. On radiomics analysis a significant association was found between the presence of lymph node metastases and 64 features. Volume-density, a measurement of shape irregularity, was the most predictive feature (p=0001, AUC=0,77, cut-off 0.35). When t esting cut-off in Group B to discriminate metastatic tumors, PET false-negative findings were reduced from 14 to 8 (-43%). Conclusions PET/CT demonstrated high specificity in detecting nodal metastases. SLN and histologic ultrastaging increased false-negative PET/CT findings, reducing the sensitivity of the technique. PET radiomics features of the primary tumor seem promising for predicting the presence of nodal metastases not detected by visual analysis.

Combining positron emission tomography/ computed tomography, radiomics, and sentinel lymph node mapping for nodal staging of endometrial cancer patients Original research

Int J Gynecol Cancer
302020. 202010.1136/ijgc-2019-000945Received 9 October 2019 Revised 31 December 2019 Accepted 6 January 2020 Methods From November 2006 to March 2019, 167378 Correspondence to CC and CL are joint first authors.
HIGHLIGHTS• Positron emission tomography/computed tomography (PET/CT) demonstrated high specificity in detecting pelvic node metastases. • Sentinel lymph node ultrastaging increased false-negative PET/CT findings, reducing the sensitivity of this technique. • PET radiomics of the primary tumor (volume-density) correlated with nodal status.

AbSTrACT

Objective To evaluate the combination of positron emission tomography/computed tomography (PET/CT) and sentinel lymph node (SLN) biopsy in women with apparent early-stage endometrial carcinoma. The correlation between radiomics features extracted from PET images of the primary tumor and the presence of nodal metastases was also analyzed.


Methods From November 2006 to March 2019, 167

patients with endometrial cancer were included. All women underwent PET/CT and surgical staging: 60/167 underwent systematic lymphadenectomy (Group 1) while, more recently, 107/167 underwent SLN biopsy (Group 2) with technetium-99m +blue dye or indocyanine green. Histology was used as standard reference. PET endometrial lesions were segmented (n=98); 167 radiomics features were computed inside tumor contours using standard Image Biomarker Standardization Initiative (IBSI) methods. Radiomics features associated with lymph node metastases were identified (Mann-Whitney test) in the training group (A); receiver operating characteristic (ROC) curves, area under the curve (AUC) values were computed and optimal cut-off (Youden index) were assessed in the test group (B).

results In Group 1, eight patients had nodal metastases (13%): seven correctly ridentified by PET/CT true-positive with one false-negative case. In Group 2, 27 patients (25%) had nodal metastases: 13 true-positive and 14 false-negative. Sensitivity, specificity, accuracy, positive predictive value, and negative predictive value of PET/ CT for pelvic nodal metastases were 87%, 94%, 93%, 70%, and 98% in Group 1 and 48%, 97%, 85%, 87%, and 85% in Group 2, respectively. On radiomics analysis a significant association was found between the presence of lymph node metastases and 64 features. Volumedensity, a measurement of shape irregularity, was the most predictive feature (p=0001, AUC=0,77, cut-off 0.35). When t esting cut-off in Group B to discriminate metastatic tumors, PET false-negative findings were reduced from 14 to 8 (-43%).

Conclusions PET/CT demonstrated high specificity in detecting nodal metastases. SLN and histologic ultrastaging increased false-negative PET/CT findings, reducing the sensitivity of the technique. PET radiomics features of the primary tumor seem promising for predicting the presence of nodal metastases not detected by visual analysis.


InTrOduCTIOn

Endometrial cancer is the most common malignancy of the female genital tract in developed countries. 1 Prognosis relies on several characteristics of the primary tumor, such as depth of myometrium invasion, grading, lymphovascular space invasion, and lymph node involvement. 2 The accurate determination of lymph node status and the extent of metastatic disease is crucial in determining the most appropriate adjuvant therapy. Although complete lymphadenectomy is included in the International Federation of Gynecology and Obstetrics (FIGO) staging of endometrial cancer, its prognostic impact remains controversial, especially in those patients with earlystage disease. [3][4][5] Prospective studies have validated sentinel lymph node (SLN) mapping and the corresponding algorithm demonstrated to be accurate with a more favorable morbidity profile with respect to comprehensive nodal dissection, even in patients with high-risk histology. 6 7 With the aim of predicting extrauterine disease pre-operatively and focusing on optimizing surgical planning, several non-invasive techniques have been evaluated, including 18 F-labeled fluoro-2-deoxyglucose (18F-FDG) positron emission tomography/computed tomography (PET/CT). In a recent metanalysis (19 studies, 1431 patients), overall pooled sensitivity and specificity of 18F-FDG PET or PET/CT in detecting lymph node metastasis were 0.68 and 0.96, respectively. 8 PET/CT falsenegative results are due to the limited spatial resolution. Thus, the introduction of SLN biopsy ultrastaging, able to identify micrometastatic deposits, may increase PET/CT false-negative findings. It has been shown for various neoplasms that tumor characteristics on images correlate with tumor molecular phenotype, genotype, and prognosis. The extraction of a large number of features from medical images and the successive mining of these features by means of machine-learning approaches is called radiomics. 9 Radiomics analysis of the uterine primary tumor on pre-operative 18F-FDG PET images may help predict the presence of metastatic lymph nodes, even when they are too small to be detected by PET, thus reducing false-negative results and increasing the sensitivity of the technique. Although preliminary data seem to confirm this hypothesis, 10 a better evaluation restricted to SLN patients and based on tools that respect the recently introduced radiomics guidelines (Image Biomarker Standardization Initiative (IBSI)) 11 is needed. The aim of this study was therefore to evaluate the role of 18F-FDG PET in women with apparent early-stage endometrial cancer considering the introduction of SLN biopsy and the predictive role of primary tumor radiomics.


Original research


MeTHOdS Population

A total of 167 endometrial cancer patients recruited from November 2006 to March 2019 who underwent a pre-operative 18F-FDG PET/ CT scan were included in the study (Table 1).

PET/CT Protocol and Image Analysis Patients were injected with 3.7 MBq/kg of 18F-FDG. PET/CT scans were performed according to the standard European Association of Nuclear Medicine (EANM) protocol 11 using integrated PET/CT systems (Discovery ST, Discovery 600, or Discovery IQ; GE Healthcare, Milwaukee, WI, USA). Image readout was performed on an Advantage Workstation 4.6 (GE Healthcare) by two nuclear medicine physicians. The diagnosis of lymph node involvement assessed on PET images was based on evidence of pathologic tracer uptake into lymph node sites identified in CT images, regardless of their size at CT.


Surgical Treatment

Surgical standard treatment by open or mini-invasive surgery included peritoneal cytology, total hysterectomy, and bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy. Systematic pelvic lymph node dissection included external iliac, superficial, and deep obturator nodes and superficial and deep common iliac nodes. SLN mapping was performed using technetium-99m (Tc-99m) plus blue dye or blue dye alone until 2014, 12 whereas from 2014 onwards fluorescent dye utilising indocyanine green (ICG) (Pulsion Medical Systems SE, Feldkirchen, Germany) was incorporated into our practice. 13 The SLN algorithm of the Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center was applied, implying that any suspicious nodes should be removed regardless of mapping. A full aortic nodal dissection (precaval and paracaval, superficial and deep intercavo-aortic and para-aortic up to renal vessels) was performed in patients with suspected 18F-FDG PET/CT findings, positive PET/CT in the pelvic area in both groups, or detection of suspicious aortic node enlargement at surgery.


Standard of Reference and Histopathologic Evaluation

Histopathologic findings were analyzed by an experienced pathologist and served as the standard of reference. In patients subjected to SLN analysis, SLNs were assessed in a standardized manner by ultrastaging and examined by immunochemistry. 12 First Analysis: Assessment of FDG-PET Performances Before/After SLN Biopsy Introduction Women were divided into two groups, depending on the adopted surgical staging. Group 1 included the 60/167 patients who underwent systematic lymphadenectomy and Group 2 the more recent 107/167 patients who underwent SLN biopsy with Tc-99m+blue dye or ICG. Absolute and percentage frequencies were used to describe categoric items of patients' population. Sensitivity, specificity, positive predictive value (PPV), negative predictive value (NPV), and accuracy of PET/CT imaging in the diagnosis of pelvic lymph node metastases were calculated based on per patient analyses.

Second Analysis: Assessment of FDG-PET Primary Tumor Radiomics Radiomics analysis was considered only for patients with a 'sure' histologic analysis, that is, patients with SLN biopsy (Group 2, 107     11 The 97 analyzed patients were divided into two groups: a training group for predictive radiomics feature identification (Group A) and a test group for predictive radiomics feature assessment (Group B). Group A included 17 true-positive and 52 true-negative patients. Group B included 14 false-negative (ie, micrometastasis) and 14 true-negative patients. For Group A, univariate association between PET radiomics features and presence of lymph node metastases was computed by Mann-Whitney test; receiver operating characteristic (ROC) curves and area under the curve (AUC) values were also computed.

Feature selection was done considering features with p≤0.05 and Spearman correlation with already selected features <0.5. Optimal cut-off for selected features was computed with the Youden index. Identified features and cut-offs were assessed in Group B.


reSuLTS


First Analysis

In Group 1, eight patients had nodal metastases (13%): seven were identified by PET/CT (true-positive) while one was not identified (false-negative). In Group 2, 27 patients were found to have nodal metastases (25%): PET gave 13 true-positive and 14 false-negative. Globally, the percentage of PET false-negatives was 1.6% in Group 1 and 13% in Group 2. Sensitivity, specificity, accuracy, PPV, and NPV of PET/CT for pelvic nodal metastases in Groups 1 and 2 are described in Table 2. Figures 1 and 2 show some clinical cases.


Second Analysis

In the training dataset (Group A) 64/167 features resulted associated with lymph node metastasis presence with p<0.05. In Table 3, P values and AUCs are shown for a group of features, including conventional PET features (metabolic tumor volume (MTV), total lesion glycolysis (TLG), standardized uptake value (SUV) maximum and mean inside the tumor), two morphologic features (solidity and volume-density) and two size zone matrix (SZM) texture features (SZM zone percentage and gray level non-uniformity (GLNU); https:// arxiv. org/ abs/ 1612. 07003). After feature selection, only one remained: volume-density, which is a morphologic feature, also called extent, defined as the ratio between the tumor volume and the volume of the smallest box containing the tumor. It generally assumes lower values for tumors with an irregular shape, which seem to have a greater probability of developing lymph node metastases. The optimal cut-off for volume-density in Group A was 0.35 (ie, tumors with a volumedensity <0.35 were more likely to be associated with lymph node metastasis). The ability of volume-density to discriminate metastatic tumors was assessed in Group B patients and the results are reported in Table 4. dISCuSSIOn SLN biopsy was shown to improve the detection of metastases by identifying lymph nodes outside the locations traditionally explored with lymphadenectomy, and by identifying low-volume disease. Indeed, ultrastaging analysis leads to a higher detection rate of micrometastases (metastatic deposits <2 mm) and isolated tumor cells 14 that might be otherwise missed by standard histologic analysis. Our study confirmed that the incidence of nodal metastases increased from 13% in the group of patients submitted to standard lymphadenectomy to 25% in the group of patients who underwent SLN biopsy. Furthermore, even if prospective data are needed to verify the reliability and the applicability of this SLN strategy in routine practice over standard lymphadenectomy in high-risk subgroups of women, [15][16][17] there is also new evidence of promising results in this subgroup of patients with apparently confined endometrial cancer.


Original research

Previous studies demonstrated high sensitivity of pre-operative PET/CT 8 for lymph node staging especially for high-risk histology; 18 similarly, high sensitivity was found in Group 1 patients (sensitivity 87%). However, these values were probably a forced overestimation because in the gold standard ('standard' histologic analysis) micrometastases were not evident. Considering SLN as the gold standard (Group 2) the sensitivity of the PET/CT technique fell from 87% to 48%.

Indeed, small metastatic lymph node lesions may remain undetected in pre-operative PET/CT scans because of limited spatial resolution (5 mm) and associated partial volume effects. 16 We obtained a higher rate of false-negative PET/CT findings when SLN was used as a gold standard (ie, from 1.6% to 13%). Considering the low sensitivity of the PET/CT technique, radiomics analysis of 18F-FDG distribution inside the primary uterine lesion was performed with the aim of helping to detect suspicious nodal metastases.

A preliminary radiomics analysis in a smaller population demonstrated that uterine tumors with a more heterogeneous FDG uptake were more likely to spread to the pelvic lymph nodes. 10 In particular, the co-presence of high and low uptake areas in the tumor (assessed by SZM ZP) was found to be associated with the presence of nodal metastases at histology, even if a pre-operative PET/ CT scan gave a negative result at the nodal level. However, this analysis was tainted as there were patients who did not undergo SLN biopsy. Furthermore, the extraction of the features in the previous study was performed with a tool that did not respect the more recently introduced IBSI standards. Here we performed the analysis on patients undergoing SLN biopsy and with tools that respected IBSI standards. Compared with previous studies, we confirmed the predictive role of MTV and TLG. Again, SUVmax was not significantly correlated with lymph node status, although it is the most widely used PET parameter in clinical practice and it is considered as an important indicator that reflects tumor aggressiveness. Among radiomics features describing the heterogeneity of uptake, SZM ZP was also confirmed to be correlated to the presence of nodal metastases; however, SZM GLNU (representing the non-uniformity of level of FDG uptake in the lesion) gave superior results to ZP. Finally, tumors with lymph node metastases were found to be generally characterized by an irregular shape and the most predictive index turned out to be volume-density. Our analysis showed that the more irregular the lesion (volume-density <0.35), the more likely the lymph nodes are pathologic. Similarly, previous studies evaluating CT imaging in head and neck cancer have found that irregularly shaped tumors were associated with a worse overall survival rate, which may reflect an increase in their aggressive behavior. 19 20 In this study we suggest integrating radiomics and the results of lymph node metastases visual detection to reduce false-negative results for a more personalized and effective surgical treatment selection. The combination of PET/CT and SLN mapping has been proposed to minimize complications and to maximize lymph node status and cure rate definition. 18 The high PPV of FDG PET allows patients positive at lymph node visual detection to be directed to lymphadenectomy, with the aim of debulking, thus avoiding SLN biopsy. Similarly, SLN biopsy is not indicated in breast cancer patients if pathologic axillary nodes are clinically evident. 21 In addition, PET/CT could be of benefit for patients in whom access to the operative field may be partly compromised (eg, patients with elevated body mass index), where the identification of enlarged or suspicious lymph nodes either in the pelvic or aortic area can be challenging or hampered by the general constitution and physical build of the patients.

However, in the case of a negative PET scan, microdisease cannot be excluded. As the prognostic value of low-volume lymph node metastases and the optimum management of this finding are not yet established, patients with isolated tumor cells and micrometastases received adjuvant chemotherapy more frequently and showed a better oncologic outcome when compared with patients with macrometastasis over a time period of 3 years. 22 23 The optimal treatment would be to carry out SLN biopsy and ultrastaging in all patients with early-stage endometrial cancer; however, this technique is not yet in widespread use in all hospitals. The


Original research

high sensitivity of the SLN algorithm for nodal staging has been demonstrated and it is not increased by the introduction of PET/ CT. Until the SLN technique becomes more widespread, radiomics could help in further stratifying the risk of nodal metastases, thus optimizing available resources. Negative PET patients with low volume-density appear to be more likely to have micrometastases and should therefore be referred for SLN biopsy and ultrastaging in tertiary-level specialized hospitals.

The main limitation of our study resides in the small number of patients. In addition, the definition of features cut-off in the training group containing macrometastases may be not optimal when used to evaluate the presence of micrometastases. However, if we apply the radiomics cut-off to negative PET results, we can identify more metastatic patients (ie, a 43% increase from 0/14 to 6/14 patients).

In conclusion, PET/CT demonstrated high specificity in detecting pelvic node metastases. SLN biopsy and histologic ultrastaging increased false-negative PET/CT findings, reducing the sensitivity of this imaging technique. PET radiomics features of the primary tumor were significantly correlated with nodal status, in particular volume-density, and could be useful in predicting the presence of nodal metastases not detected on visual analysis. However, larger prospective and cost-effective analyses are needed to clarify the clinical impact of the combination of these techniques.

Figure 1

Figure 2
2False-negative PET/CT finding. No pathologic uptake was detected, while sentinel lymph node biopsy and ultrastaging demonstrated a micrometastases in the left external iliac site.
